question: [File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Staleness Attack] Line 47 only checks max_staleness_seconds > 0, so can an attacker set it to 1 second, causing all oracle updates older than 1 second to be rejected in valid_update_indices at aggregator.move line 574, resulting in constant 'no valid updates' failures? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Price Manipulation] Can an attacker set max_staleness_seconds to MAX_U64 (effectively infinite), allowing the aggregator to accept oracle data from months or years ago, enabling attacks where manipulated historical prices are used for current vault valuations? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Staleness Conversion] When max_staleness_seconds is multiplied by 1000 to convert to milliseconds at aggregator.move line 341, can setting max_staleness_seconds close to MAX_U64/1000 cause overflow in the multiplication, wrapping to a very small staleness window? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Staleness Bypass] If max_staleness_seconds is set to 1 and then immediately increased to 1000000, can an attacker exploit the window where legitimate updates were rejected to force the vault to rely on their manipulated price feed? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Clock Manipulation] Since valid_update_indices compares (timestamp_ms + max_staleness_ms) < now_ms, can an attacker set max_staleness_seconds to 0 (fails at line 47) but what if they set it to 1, effectively making now_ms checks always exclude valid recent updates? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [TOCTOU] Between validate() reading aggregator state at line 86-93 and actuate() modifying it at line 95-102, can a concurrent transaction call add_result() changing current_result, causing config updates to apply to a different aggregator state than was validated? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Race Condition] Can two authority transactions call run() simultaneously on the same shared aggregator, both passing validate() with version=1, but the second transaction's actuate() applies configs assuming a state that was already modified by the first transaction? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [State Mutation] Since actuate() is not public entry and can only be called by run(), does this prevent reentrancy, or can a malicious module in the same package call actuate() directly after validate() but before run() completes? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Atomicity] Is the validate-then-actuate pattern atomic in Sui's execution model? Can a transaction abort after validate() succeeds but before actuate() completes, leaving the aggregator in a partially validated state? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Suppression] If event::emit at line 66 fails silently or is ignored, can config changes at line 58 occur without any on-chain event record, allowing authority to secretly manipulate aggregator configs without detection? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Ordering] Can an attacker front-run legitimate config updates, causing AggregatorConfigsUpdated events to be emitted out of order, confusing off-chain systems that track config changes chronologically? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Data Integrity] The event at lines 66-73 includes the new config values - if set_configs at line 58 partially fails but event still emits, can the event show config values that were never actually applied to the aggregator? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Event Replay] Can an attacker observe historical AggregatorConfigsUpdated events and replay the transaction with the same parameters, causing unnecessary config changes that revert important security updates? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Deletion Race] Can an attacker call aggregator_delete_action concurrently with run(), causing set_configs at line 58 to be applied to an aggregator that's being deleted, potentially corrupting deletion cleanup or causing undefined behavior? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Authority Race] If aggregator_set_authority_action is called between has_authority check at line 42 and set_configs at line 58, can the new authority's config update be rejected even though they should have permission? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Result Pollution] If add_result() is called with malicious oracle data during the run() execution, can the new configs validate that malicious data retroactively by changing min_sample_size or max_variance to accept the bad results? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Queue Mismatch] Since validate() doesn't check if the feed_hash matches the aggregator's queue, can an attacker set configs for a feed_hash that belongs to a different queue, causing oracle routing errors? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Integer Overflow] When max_staleness_seconds is converted to milliseconds via multiplication by 1000 in valid_update_indices, can setting max_staleness_seconds > MAX_U64/1000 cause silent overflow resulting in a tiny staleness window instead of intended large one? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: validate()] [Type Limits] Since min_responses is u32 but compared against u64 lengths in compute_current_result, can setting min_responses = MAX_U32 = 4294967295 create inconsistencies with min_sample_size which uses u64 range? (Low)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: actuate()] [Numeric Bounds] Can max_variance be set to values that cause arithmetic overflow in variance computation at aggregator.move line 395 where m2/(count-1) could overflow u256? (Medium)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Manipulation Setup] Can an attacker with authority: 1) set min_sample_size=1 and min_responses=1 via run(), 2) collude with one oracle to submit manipulated price, 3) use that price in Volo Vault operations before legitimate oracles can update? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Price Freeze Attack] Can an attacker: 1) set max_staleness_seconds=1 via run(), 2) DoS oracle update transactions to prevent any updates, 3) force Volo Vault to use increasingly stale current_result until operations fail or revert to outdated prices? (High)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Variance Manipulation] Can an attacker: 1) set max_variance=MAX_U64 via run(), 2) submit fake oracle updates with extreme variance, 3) cause compute_current_result to accept manipulated mean/stdev that misrepresent actual consensus? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Feed Swap Attack] Can an attacker: 1) create two aggregators with different feeds (SUI/USD and attacker-controlled feed), 2) swap feed_hash on the production aggregator to point to their feed, 3) control vault price oracle without anyone noticing until vault operations execute? (Critical)

[File: volo-vault/local_dependencies/switchboard_sui/on_demand/sources/actions/aggregator/aggregator_set_configs_action.move] [Function: run()] [Vault Oracle DoS] If this aggregator is used by Volo Vault's oracle price config and authority sets min_sample_size higher than available oracle count, does the vault's get_price() fail, blocking all deposits/withdrawals/operations? (High)
